metadata.title: DINNER PARTY LABYRINTH . Act 1: The Arrival
metadata.description: A social survival game. You've been invited to dinner at the Weissmans'. The invitation said 7:30. You arrived at 7:47. This will be discussed.
metadata.author: Studio BGC

skills._comment: Disco Elysium-inspired inner voices that comment on social situations

COMPOSURE.description: Stay calm. Don't let them see you sweat.

EMPATHY.description: Feel what they feel. Sometimes too much.

VOLITION.description: Your will to continue. To not run away.

INLAND_EMPIRE.description: The weird. The uncanny. The feeling something is wrong.

LOGIC.description: Make it make sense. Find the pattern.

RHETORIC.description: The right words. The winning argument.

characters.name: YOU
characters.description: Art history professor. Divorced. The kind of tired that sleep doesn't fix.
characters.flaw: You observe instead of participate. Safety in distance.
characters.want: To feel like you belong somewhere again.

characters.name: Mara
characters.description: Former cellist. Gave it up at 32 when she realized she'd only ever be 'good.' Now she controls what she can.
characters.philosophy: If you can't control the big things, control the small ones perfectly.
characters.flaw: Her need for perfection makes everyone feel inadequate, including herself.
characters.want: To be seen as more than 'Eli's wife' or 'the hostess.'
characters.obsession: The 17-minute napkin folding video. Butter temperatures. The colander's spot.
characters.secret: She invited you because she remembered something about you that you've forgotten.

characters.name: Eli
characters.description: Insurance adjuster by day. Has 43 vintage radios in various states of repair. Married to Mara for 11 years (or 12, depending on how you count).
characters.philosophy: Things can be fixed if you're patient enough. People are just complicated things.
characters.flaw: He retreats into his hobbies when emotions get complicated.
characters.want: For Mara to look at him the way she looks at a perfectly set table.
characters.obsession: The radios. Specifically, one that picks up signals that shouldn't exist.
characters.secret: He knows about the break. He pretends not to remember it differently than she does.

characters.name: Dana
characters.description: Mara's college friend. Works in 'consulting' (she's vague about what). Laughs at jokes before they end because she's already figured out where they're going.
characters.philosophy: People are exactly who they pretend not to be.
characters.flaw: She sees through everyone but won't let anyone see through her.
characters.want: To find someone who surprises her.
characters.secret: She's not here for Mara. She's here for you.

scenes.name: The Entryway
scenes.location: The Weissman Apartment - A brownstone with exposed brick that cost extra

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Oh! You found it. Some people have trouble with the address—the numbers skip on this block. But you found it.
nodes.stageDirections: [Mara is holding a wooden spoon. She does not put it down.]

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: The buzzer's been acting up. Shoes are optional—most people take them off, but it's not a rule or anything.
nodes.stageDirections: [Eli is wearing socks with individual toes.]

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I brought Sancerre. Mara said not to bring anything, so.
nodes.stageDirections: [Dana is already holding a glass of something that is not Sancerre.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: That's so sweet. We'll definitely open it. Eli, can you take their—is that a jacket or a coat? I can never tell anymore.

outputs.label: It's a jacket. Sorry I'm late.
Whatever you want it to be.
I can hold it. I run cold.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: It's a jacket. I'm sorry I'm late—the 6 train was backed up at 51st.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: The 6? From where you live? That's... I would have said take the L, but you're here now.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I took a car. Is that bad? Mara made a face when I said car.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: I didn't make a face. I just think if you live in a city with public transit... never mind. How are you? You're still teaching at—where is it again?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: It can be whatever you need it to be.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: That's... okay. We're doing that kind of evening. Eli, did you hear that?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I had a coat once that could be either. Zip-off sleeves. German. I don't know what happened to it.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I think I donated it.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: You. that was two hundred. why would you—

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I didn't. I'm kidding. I don't know where your coat is, Eli.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I'll hold it. I run cold. Always have.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Do you? Eli runs hot. Don't you. He opens windows in February. I've stopped fighting it.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: The human body is meant to adapt to cold. There's research—the Scandinavians have done studies. We just have different metabolisms.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I'm always exactly the right temperature. It's my only skill.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You hand over the jacket without comment.]

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: This is heavier than I expected. What's in here, rocks?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Eli, don't—I'm sorry, he does this. Comments on the weight of things.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I'm just saying it's heavier than expected. That's an observation. Is that not allowed?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Wine? Dana brought Sancerre, which needs to chill a bit more. And there's the Grüner Eli found at that place, the one that closed—

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: It didn't close. They moved. There's a difference.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: They moved to New Jersey. For wine purposes, that's closed.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: The Grüner sounds perfect. I trust your taste.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: See? Someone appreciates it. I spent forty minutes in that store before they moved.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Eli, the Grüner is for the fish. We discussed this. It's been breathing.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: White wine doesn't need to breathe. But fine. Fine.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Water's fine for now. I'll catch up.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Catch up. That's ominous. Are you drinking competitively?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: No, I just—it came out wrong. Whatever's open is fine.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Nothing's open yet. That's why I asked. Eli, can you get the one from the thing?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: What else do you have? I'm curious now.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: We have red, white, and orange. Yes, orange wine is a thing—Eli made a face when I bought it.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I didn't make a face. I have a face. Sometimes it does things.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Can I have more of what I'm having? I don't know what it is but I like it.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: That's the—Eli, which one did you give Dana?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I don't remember. One of them. Does it matter? They're all good.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Why don't we move to the dining room? The food needs another few minutes.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: So, how do you two know each other? Mara's been evasive about it.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: We met at—do you want to tell it, or should I?

outputs.label: You tell it. You're better at stories.
We met through mutual. it's complicated.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: You tell it. You're better at stories.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Am I? Okay. We met at—god, what was it? A fundraiser? No. A funeral. Was it a funeral?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: It was a bookstore. That closed. You were buying—

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: A bookstore! The one with the cat that bit people. What was I buying?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Cookbooks. You always buy cookbooks. You have forty. You use three.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: I use more than three. But the point is, we met. We're here now.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: We met through mutual friends. It's complicated. Overlapping circles.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Overlapping circles. That sounds like a cult.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: It wasn't a cult. Dana, why would you say that?

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I'm joking. Although you did say overlapping circles out loud.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I don't actually remember. Isn't that strange? I remember that we met.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: You don't remember? I was wearing that green dress. You said you liked my earrings.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I remember the green dress. The rest is fuzzy. Does that happen to you? Time collapsing?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Time collapsing. Is that a medical thing?

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I think it's a metaphor, Eli.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: I should check on the oven. Excuse me.
nodes.stageDirections: [Mara exits. The wooden spoon goes with her.]

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: She's nervous. She wants tonight to go well. You know how she gets.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: How does she get? I'm new here.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: She gets focused. The butter has to be room temperature. There's a whole thing with the napkins.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: What thing with the napkins?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: They have to be folded a specific way. There's a YouTube video, seventeen minutes long. I've seen it four times.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Four times is a lot for napkins.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: That's what I said. Anyway, she cares. Even if the caring gets intense.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Should I offer to help? In the kitchen?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: No. God, no. There's a system. I moved a colander once. We didn't speak for a day.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: A colander? The thing with holes?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: It has a spot. Everything has a spot.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I'm going to. where's the—

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Down the hall. First door. Don't use the second door.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: What's behind the second door?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: His office. The radios. You can look but actually, don't. They're in a delicate phase.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You walk down the hall. The first door is marked. The second is not.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Okay! The first course is ready. It's nothing elaborate, just a little amuse-bouche.
nodes.stageDirections: [Mara returns. The wooden spoon is gone.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [The bathroom is immaculate. There are three different hand soaps. All lavender.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You look at your face in the mirror. It looks tired. When did you start looking tired?]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [The door opens. There are radios. So many radios. Some of them are on.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [One of them is playing something. Static. Or music. Hard to tell.]

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I said don't—oh. You're in there. Okay. What do you think?

outputs.label: It's impressive. How many are there?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: It's impressive. How many are there?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Forty-three. Forty-four if you count the broken one. Mara says it's a problem. I say it's a collection.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: What is that one playing?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I don't know. It does that. Sometimes. Picks things up. Old signals, maybe. Or new ones that sound old. I've stopped asking.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I should go back—

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You stand in the hall. From the kitchen, voices.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: —don't know why I invited them. At the time it seemed like a good idea—

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: —fine. Everything's fine. You always do this. You invite people and then—

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: —I'm not upset. There's just something about them I can't explain—

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: There you are! We should eat before things get cold. Or too hot. Depending.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [The table is set. The napkins are folded into shapes you don't recognize.]

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Mara, these napkins are incredible. What are they supposed to be?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Swans. They're swans. You can't tell they're swans?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: They look like swans. Very swan-like.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I thought they were something else. Never mind. Swans. Yes. I see it now.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [The first course arrives. It is very small. Almost conceptually small.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Don't eat it yet. There's a specific way to eat it. Let me explain.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Mara. It's food. You put it in your mouth.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: The chef at that place we went—the small place in the Village—said you're supposed to let it rest on your tongue first. But eat it however you want. I don't care.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: You clearly care.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Fine. You're supposed to eat the crispy part first, then the soft part. There's a third part underneath.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You eat the crispy part. Then the soft part. You wait.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: See? They're doing it right. Eli, look. Someone listens.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I listen. I just don't need eating instructions. It feels like a lot.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You eat it in one bite. It's actually very good.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Oh. You just ate it. Okay. That works too, I guess.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: How is it?

outputs.label: I can't tell. I ate it too fast.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Really good, actually.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Is it? Good. I wasn't sure about the reduction. Anyway, good.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I can't tell. I ate it too fast.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: At least you're honest. Eli does that too. Inhales food. Doesn't taste anything.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I taste things. I taste things fast. It's efficient.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: What's the third part?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: It's underneath. You have to lift the crispy layer. Here, let me show you—

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [Mara reaches across the table. Her sleeve grazes your water glass. The glass tilts.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You catch the glass. Water sloshes but doesn't spill.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Oh! Good reflexes. I'm sorry, I shouldn't have reached. I get very hands-on. Eli says it's a problem.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [The glass falls. Water spreads across the tablecloth. The napkin swans absorb it slowly.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: The tablecloth—it was my grandmother's. It's fine. Everything's fine.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: It's not her grandmother's. She bought it at that home goods store in SoHo.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Eli, please. Just get the club soda.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You push the food around your plate. You're not hungry. Or you are, but not for this.]

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Not hungry?

outputs.label: I ate before. I shouldn't have.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I ate before. I shouldn't have. I was nervous.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Nervous? About what? About us? We're very relaxed people. Aren't we relaxed, Eli?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: We're working on it.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Just pacing myself. There are more courses, right?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Four courses. Five if you count the amuse-bouche. Then dessert. Then a palate cleanser. It's not important.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You say nothing. The silence expands.]

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Okay then.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: So. What do you do? I know you teach. Mara mentioned teaching. But she didn't say what.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: I did mention it. Didn't I? I feel like I said something.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: You said 'teaches' and then changed the subject. It was very smooth. I almost didn't notice.

outputs.label: I'd rather not talk about work.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: History. Art history, specifically. Renaissance, mostly. Sometimes. it depends on the semester.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Art history! In college I almost majored in that. But I sell insurance now. Radio is the hobby.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: The radios are a hobby? I assumed they were. I don't know. A condition.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: It's not a condition. They're vintage. They have value. Anyway, art history. That's interesting. Tell me something.

outputs.label: Did you know there's a painting that might be haunted?
There's nothing interesting about art history.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Did you know there's a painting—well, not haunted exactly. But there's a Caravaggio where people who owned it kept dying. Badly.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Death at dinner? Okay. I can work with that.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: There's nothing interesting about art history. That's the secret. We just look at things until they mean something.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: That's the most honest thing anyone's said all night.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Does it matter? What I teach?

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Probably not. I'm just making conversation. That's what we do here, right? Make conversation?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: We're not just making conversation. Dana, you're being—

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: What? Direct? Honest? I thought that's what we were doing.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I'd rather not talk about work. Is that okay?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Of course. We don't have to talk about work. What else is there? Travel? Hobbies? Fears?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Fears?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: I don't know. I'm brainstorming. What do people talk about?

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Usually work. Or kids. Or real estate. The boring trinity.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I should check on the next course. Excuse me.
nodes.stageDirections: [Eli exits to the kitchen. You hear something clatter.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: The kitchen is his domain. He has a system. Like I have a system. Different systems. Competing systems.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: How long have you two been married? Together? What's the word?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Eleven years. Or twelve. It depends on what you're counting from.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: What are the options?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: First date. First real date. The wedding. There was a break in the middle. We don't count the break.

outputs.label: Eleven years is a long time.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: What happened during the break?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Nothing. Everything. The usual things that happen during breaks. I shouldn't have mentioned it.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I didn't ask about the break. They asked about the break. I asked about the years.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Right. Yes. You're right. Sorry. Things come out before I can stop them. Is it warm in here?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Eleven years is a long time.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Is it? Some days it feels long. Most days it doesn't. The days blur.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: The days blur. That's either romantic or depressing. I can't tell which.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Both. Neither. It depends on the day.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: This wine is good. What is it? I forgot to ask.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Oh, that's the one Eli found. At the place I told you about. The one that moved.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: To New Jersey. I remember. Wine purgatory.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Ha. Wine purgatory. I'm going to tell Eli you said that. He won't like it, but I'll tell him anyway.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: The second course—there's been a development.
nodes.stageDirections: [Eli returns. He is holding a colander. There is no explanation for the colander.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: A development? Why are you holding the colander?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: I moved it. Deliberately. I'm making a point.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: What point? What is the point? Eli, the colander has a spot—

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Everything has a spot! Everything! And if I move one thing, it's a crisis. It's always a crisis.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Should we be here for this?

outputs.label: Maybe we should give you two a minute.
The colander isn't the point, is it?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You say nothing. You watch.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: I need things to be in order. If I can't control the small things, how am I supposed to—

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: Control the big things? Is that what we're calling it? Control?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Can we do this later? We have guests. This is not the time.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Maybe we should give you two a minute.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: No! We're fine. This is just how we are. It's fine. Sit. Please. Eli, put the colander back.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: No.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Eli.

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: ...fine.
nodes.stageDirections: [Eli exits. The colander goes with him.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: The colander isn't the point, is it?

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: I. what?

nodes.speaker: char_partner
nodes.text: No. It's not.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Why are we doing this now? This is a dinner party. This is supposed to be nice.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: It is nice. This is very nice. Best dinner party I've been to in years.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: The second course will be ready soon. I should go help with the colander situation.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [Mara exits. You are alone with Dana. The radios in the other room are making a sound. Not static. Something else.]

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: So. How do you really know them?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I told you. The bookstore.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Right. The bookstore with the cat. The one that bit people. Did it bite you?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Yes. It did.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Interesting. Mara always said the cat only bit people it liked. She has a theory about it.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: No. It didn't. I was careful.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Careful. You seem like the careful type. Is that working out for you? Being careful?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I don't know. Not really. Some people you meet and then. they're just there. In your life. You don't remember inviting them.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: That's. I don't know what that is. Honest? Sad? A cry for help?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: All three, probably.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: I like you. I think. I'm still deciding.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Why do you ask?

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Because Mara mentioned you. A lot. Before tonight. More than she mentions most people. And she couldn't tell me why. Which is. unusual. For her.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: What did she say?

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Nothing specific. That's what was strange. Just. your name. In different contexts. Like you were a piece of furniture she kept rearranging.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [From the kitchen, voices. The colander has returned. Or hasn't. You can't tell.]

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Should we check on them? Or sit here, drink more wine, and pretend things are normal?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Let's check on them.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You walk toward the kitchen. The door is slightly open. The colander is on the counter. Mara is crying. Eli is holding her. They don't see you.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Pretend. I'm good at pretend.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Are you? That's useful. Actually, that's sad. But useful.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You drink more wine. The radios continue to make that sound. Dana watches you. You watch the door.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: What is normal, really?

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Oh god. Philosophy. At this hour? With this wine?

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I'm serious. What's normal? I can't remember the last time something felt expected.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: That's actually concerning. Are you okay? Real question.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: No. I don't think I am.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Okay. That's. I don't know what to do with that. But thank you for saying it.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: Yes. I'm fine. It was just a moment. I'm fine.

nodes.speaker: char_guest1
nodes.text: Right. Fine. The most convincing word.

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: I don't know. I genuinely don't know.

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Okay! The second course! It exists. It's here.
nodes.stageDirections: [Mara returns. Her eyes are slightly red. Her smile is perfect.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [The second course is placed before you. It is larger than the first. But somehow, it feels smaller.]

nodes.speaker: char_p
nodes.text: [You clear your throat. They pull apart.]

nodes.speaker: char_host
nodes.text: Oh! I was just—allergies. There's something in the air. Anyway, the second course!
